In practice, unless Mauritians are willing to acknowledge their own identity and stand by it there is no hope.  Politicians generally work to appease the mass and earn votes to be/remain in office. If they think that the population want to be European and deny the identity of the country; politicians will act accordingly and turn the country into a European replica.  My family of five migrated from Mauritius fifty years ago.  In my early years I was brought up in a typical Mauritian environment.   Until recently, I have been away from the Mauritius and the community. Late last year, I spent six weeks in Mauritius to discover that Mauritians look down on people who do not speak French.  Incidentally, I do not speak French, however, Creole my maternal language came straight back to me.  I spoke Creole everywhere I went to be met with people replying in French. There is this sense that only  people of lesser status use the language.   What is Mauritian identity if it is not demonstrated by its local language?Words will not cut it, Mauritians ought to learn to own and be proud of their roots. title: Marie-Josee Clency - Mama Mo Oule Marier
comments: Like the person below, I lived in South Africa, but my parents were French Mauritian. I love the sega music, the creole language, the food. I grew up listening to Serge Labrasse, Roger and Marie Josee Clency, Guy Antoinette. Wish I was there now. | OMG! This is my childhood, people! I’m a very proud british-Mauritian, born and bred in East London by wonderful and loving Mauritian parents, who are dearly missed. My childhood was filled with a rich Mauritian culture with hints of Britishness, and yes, my siblings and I are fluent in Mauritian Creole, but I didn’t know how unique my mother made our Creole until visiting families in Mauritius and France as our Creole had a lot of English and even a hint of cockney. And being a British-Mauritian family, we grew up on Mauritian cuisine, my mother a phenomenal cook and adding a twist of English cuisine to it. And our Mauritian family parties was magical, filled with laughter and Mauritian Sega, this particular song being played multiple times, and that’s in one party, even non-Mauritian at our family parties loved the tempo and dancing to Mauritian Sega until on the verge of popping the hips out. Whoever posted this video, thank you so much for igniting my memories of happier time | j'adore ce sega, merci marie josee pour cette chanson | que de bons souvenirs !!! | Sa lé quel année sa?
